results.title: Taps and toilets
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Waterworks”.
Episode 4, ‘Taps and toilets’, deals with how human usage plays a role in the water cycle. Areas of human usage (both industrial and domestic) are discussed from the source point to the processes used for the purification of waste-water. Increased demand for water has highlighted long-standing problems with water supply including pollution. Forms of pollution discussed are tree clearing, salination and rainwater (carrying pesticides etc to our bays). Also discussed are unconfined aquifers (which explains our Billabongs), and confined aquifers like the Artesian Basin. Narrated by writer and producer Dick Beilby, this program creates relationships between our use of water and broader climatic environment beyond the taps and toilets - “the part of the water cycle that mostly connect with our lives”.

results.title: Floating, sinking, swimming
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Waterworks”.
‘Floating, sinking and swimming’, the third in the series, primarily deals with physics principles that explain the nature of water in relation to our use of it. The rules for floating and sinking are discussed, with Archimedes’ Principle that went further to describe the physics of buoyancy. Pressure, force and density are explained with examples (like the construction of wetsuits and submarines) that differentiate how water pressure relates to solids and liquids. Presented by series producer Dick Beilby.

results.title: Amazing H2o
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Waterworks”.
‘Episode 2: amazing H2O’ starts with the story of Henry Cavendish (Mark Allen), a rich scientist in the 17th century who made it his mission in life to discover the properties of water. His persistence gave us the H2O chemical name. With 70% of the earth covered in water, it is surprising to learn that scientists know more about the qualities of ice than water itself. Exploring both the realm of the known and unknown, this episode covers the following topics; surface tension, anti-gravitational behaviour, solutions, emulsions, ice, gas, evaporation, crystals. Presented by series producer Dick Beilby.

results.title: The Water planet
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Waterworks”.
‘Waterworks’ is an in depth series produced by the ABC on water and covers areas such as; human usage, molecular properties and the role of water in the ecology. ‘The Water planet’, first in the series, details broadly the concepts that govern the function of water and investigates the presence of water on earth and in space. The film starts with the premise that all life on earth is based on water and digresses to detail this relationship. The following subjects are covered from the presence of water in space, water cycles, water ecology, function of chemical parts in water, weather patterns and its relationship to water, water and plantlife, the oceans. Presented by series producer Dick Beilby.

results.title: Millenium Dilemma: Constitutional Change in Australia
results.creator_credit: Jane Innes and University of Wollongong
results.brief_description: A five part series which analyses the Australian Constitution and its prospects for change in the 21st century. The programs discuss a variety of issues related to the Australian constitution, with each focusing on specific subjects that define the content of the interviews with and commentary from politicians, academics, media commentators and legal counsel that make up each episode. The subjects covered by the series include the history of the Australian Constitution and its founding ideals, the possible make up of an Australian Republic and the necessary adaptations to the Constitution, the Australian Parliament and the Executive as well as their distribution of powers, the rights and guarantees contained in the Constitution for the community, issues of aboriginal reconciliation in the Constitution and the future of the Constitution through the political channels for change such as referendums.

results.title: Constitutional futures
results.creator_credit: Jane Innes and University of Wollongong
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Millenium Dilemma: Constitutional Change in Australia”.
The final episode in the “Millennium dilemma” series explores the potential future of the Constitution and the facilities in the current political system that could be employed to institute change. Through commentary from a range of contributors a variety of subjects are discussed including Section 128 of the Australian Constitution, the notion of a citizens referenda and how the community can relate to and have power in the alteration of the Constitution. These contributors include politicians, political analysts, media commentators, academics and legal counsel such as Professor Michael Coper, Dr Helen Irving, Noel Pearson, Sir Zelman Cowan QC and Sir Anthony Mason.

results.title: Rights and wrongs
results.creator_credit: Jane Innes and University of Wollongong
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Millenium Dilemma: Constitutional Change in Australia”.
The fourth episode in the “Millennium dilemma” series explores the rights and guarantees for the population contained in the Australian Constitution and in tandem discusses past and present issues of Aboriginal reconciliation. At the opening of the program questions are put forward about the writing of the rights to be included in an altered Australian Constitution such as, should there be an entrenched Bill of Rights? Should there be a Statutory Bill of Rights? What other rights and guarantees should be written into the Constitution? Particular attention is also paid to the issues of Aboriginal reconciliation and how it should be written into and recognised in the Australian Constitution. This is followed by responsive commentary from a range of contributors on these subjects. These interviewees include politicians, political analysts, media commentators, academics and legal counsel such as Quentin Bryce, Professor John Goldring, Chief Justice Murray Gleeson, Helen Irving, Sue Tongue and Professor George Winterton.

results.title: The Power game
results.creator_credit: Jane Innes and University of Wollongong
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Millenium Dilemma: Constitutional Change in Australia”.
The third episode in the “Millennium dilemma” series explores the division of power in the Parliament and the Executive in Australia, with particular attention to Federal and State Powers and their differences. The program offers definitions of and discussions about Parliament and the Executive as well as Federal, State and Local governments by the range of contributors to the program, along with their responsive commentary about questions such as, is there a ‘State and Federal Fiscal Imbalance? What is the power of external affairs? These interviewees include politicians, political analysts, media commentators, academics and legal counsel such as Professor Brian Galligan, UN member Elizabeth Evatt, Justice Michael Kirby, Kim Rubenstein, Kristen Walker, Sir Ninian Stephen and Professor Cheryl Saunders.

results.title: An Australian Republic?
results.creator_credit: Jane Innes and University of Wollongong
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Millenium Dilemma: Constitutional Change in Australia”.
The second episode in the “Millennium dilemma” series explores the notion of an Australian Republic and the potential changes in the Constitution this would require and how they would be determined. At the opening of the program questions are put forward such as, what would the role, functions and powers of the Head of State be? Would the Head of State be elected or selected within government? What impact would an Australian Republic have on the States? This is followed by responsive commentary from a range of contributors on these subjects. These interviewees include politicians, political analysts, media commentators, academics and legal counsel such as Professor Michael Coper, UN member Elizabeth Evatt, Noel Pearson, Professor Leslie Zines and His Excellency the Honourable Richard McGarvie.
results.description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Millenium Dilemma: Constitutional Change in Australia”.
The second episode in the “Millennium dilemma” series explores the notion of an Australian Republic and the potential changes in the Constitution this would require and how they would be determined. At the opening of the program questions are put forward such as, what would the role, functions and powers of the Head of State be? Would the Head of State be elected or selected within government? What impact would an Australian Republic have on the States? This is followed by responsive commentary from a range of contributors on these subjects. These interviewees include politicians, political analysts, media commentators, academics and legal counsel such as Professor Michael Coper, UN member Elizabeth Evatt, Noel Pearson, Professor Leslie Zines and His Excellency the Honourable Richard McGarvie.
description_for_label:
Episode number 2 of Series “Millenium Dilemma: Constitutional Change in Australia”.
The second episode in the “Millennium dilemma” series explores the notion of an Australian Republic and the potential changes in the Constitution this would require and how they would be determined. At the opening of the program questions are put forward such as, what would the role, functions and powers of the Head of State be? Would the Head of State be elected or selected within government? What impact would an Australian Republic have on the States? This is followed by responsive commentary from a range of contributors on these subjects. These interviewees include politicians, political analysts, media commentators, academics and legal counsel such as Professor Michael Coper, UN member Elizabeth Evatt, Noel Pearson, Professor Leslie Zines and His Excellency the Honourable Richard McGarvie.
